title: 105_s2347
content: The Act may be cited as the Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act and aims to expand prevention efforts for methamphetamine abuse. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act aims to prevent methamphetamine abuse by providing grants for school-based and community-based prevention programs. The Director of the Center for Substance Abuse Prevention can make grants to public and non-profit entities for effective and evidence-based prevention programs. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act provides grants for school-based and community-based prevention programs targeting populations at high risk for methamphetamine abuse. Local government entities can also receive assistance for methamphetamine prevention activities. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act provides grants for prevention activities, training for law enforcement officials, planning, administration, monitoring, evaluation, and pilot programs to encourage innovation in methamphetamine prevention. The Director prioritizes grants for areas with high methamphetamine abuse rates. $500,000 annually is allocated for analyses and evaluations of prevention programs, with reports submitted to specific Senate committees. The Senate and House committees receive an annual report on analyses and evaluations of prevention programs. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1999, with additional funding for future years. SEC. 3. EXPANDING CRIMINAL PENALTIES AND LAW ENFORCEMENT FUNDING. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend sentencing guidelines for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine in violation of drug laws. The base offense level will be increased for these offenses. The base offense level for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine will be increased by at least 3 levels above the current level or to level 27 if lower. If the offense poses a substantial risk of danger to others, the base offense level will be increased by at least 6 levels. The base offense level for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine will be increased by at least 6 levels above the current level or to level 30 if lower. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to implement these changes promptly after the enactment of the Act. Increased resources for law enforcement to combat methamphetamine trafficking in high intensity drug trafficking areas are authorized, with $25,000,000 allocated for fiscal year 1999 and additional funding for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. The amendments made under this Act will apply to offenses occurring 60 days after enactment. SEC. 4. TREATMENT OF METHAMPHETAMINE ABUSE. Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for expanding treatment programs for methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Funds can be used for evidence-based programs to help individuals quit methamphetamine use. The amended Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act allows grants for expanding treatment programs for methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including evidence-based programs, training for health professionals, planning and administration activities, and monitoring and evaluation of treatment activities. The Director shall prioritize grants for rural and urban areas with high rates of methamphetamine abuse. Up to $1,000,000 is allocated for analyses and evaluation of treatment programs. The Director will receive up to $1,000,000 annually for analyzing and evaluating effective treatments for methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Reports on these evaluations will be submitted to relevant Senate and House committees. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is included for the analyses and evaluation conducted for effective treatments for methamphetamine abuse and addiction, with $40,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 1999 and additional funds for each succeeding fiscal year. SEC. 5. EXPANDING METHAMPHETAMINE RESEARCH. Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, focusing on its effects on the human body, addictive nature, connection to mental illness, and prevention methods. The amended Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act allows grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction. This research includes identifying prevention methods, effective treatment options, risk factors, effects on pregnant women and fetuses, and reasons for methamphetamine abuse. The Director is responsible for disseminating research results to relevant entities, with an authorization of $16,000,000 for this purpose. The amended Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act authorizes grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, with an appropriation of $16,000,000 for fiscal year 1999 and additional funding for subsequent years.
